oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Resveratrol inhibits type II phosphatidylinositol 4-kinase: a key component in pathways of phosphoinositide turn over
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: SRIVASTAVA, RUPA
RATHEESH, APARNA
GUDE, RAJIV K
RAO, KVK
PANDA, DULAL
SUBRAHMANYAM, GOSUKONDA
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: signal transduction
infiltration
cell adhesion
enzymes
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Resveratrol has anti-inflammatory, cardio protective and cancer chemopreventive properties. The molecular targets for resveratrol in early signaling cascades are not well understood. Resveratrol inhibits type II PtdIns 4-kinase but not PtdIns 3-kinase activity in vitro. Resveratrol directly binds to the enzyme with a Kd of 7.2 Î¼M. Kinetic studies show that resveratrol competes with PtdIns binding. Inhibition of PtdIns 4-kinase activity by resveratrol/phenylarsine oxide reduces Jurkat cell adhesion to matrigel/fibronectin coated surfaces, suggesting a role for type II PtdIns 4-kinase in lymphocyte infiltration to the sites of inflammation.
